--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Umer Iqbal"
> <umeriqbal81@h...> wrote:
> > 
> > Regarding the fact that the net that evolved had
> 44 neurons:
> > 
> > There must be more than on solution to the given
> problem. And as I
> myself have come across some solutions (to another
> problem posted
> earlier) that are equally as good but vary in
> network complexity
> (number of neurons and connections varied in order
> of tens), I must
> say that 44 neurons might be just one possible
> solution. And that NEAT
> might have missed a simpler solution earlier in the
> evolution process
> due to some reason. 
> > 
> > Now, If my above statements are correct, then what
> could be the
> possible reasons why NEAT missed the simpler
> solution/s? Was it
> because that we complexified at a rate higher than
> we should have? or
> was it just because of the nature of evolutionary
> process itself? or
> was it due to some other reason? 
> > and what can we do about it?
> > 
> 
> I think in this experiment Mitchell did not use
> NEAT.  He just used a
> standard fixed-sized fully-recurrent network.  I
> think that's why he
> uploaded the code for this experiment- so that
> someone on this group
> might attempt it with NEAT.  It would definitely be
> interesting to see
> what NEAT would come up with.

That is correct.  I write my code in straight C, not
C++.  My ANN has a fixed number of neurons during one
run of the program, although I can change it easily
for subsequent runs.  I tried fairly hard to evolve
4-card players with 36, 38 & 40 neurons, without
success, but that does not prove its impossible.  They
all surpassed the 85% win level.  My experience is
that its very hard to evolve to the 100% level with
this game and this ANN and this software.  Most runs
with 44 neurons don't get there.

=====
Mitchell Timin
http://annevolve.sourceforge.net
